case_name: State of U.P. v. Jogendra Singh

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 301 of 1961 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 301 of 1961.

facts.text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated March 10, 1960, of the Allahabad High Court Lucknow Bench in Special Appeal No. 40 of 1959.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated March 10, 1960, of the Allahabad High Court  Lucknow Bench  in Special Appeal No. 40 of 1959.

facts.text: The judgment was delivered on March 4, 1963 by GAJENDRAGADKAR J.

anchor.surface_text: 1963. March 4. The judgment of the Court was delivered by GAJENDRAGADKAR J .-

facts.text: Respondent Jogendra Singh was appointed a Naib Tehsildar under the State of U.P. in 1937.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent Jogendra Singh was appointed a Naib Tehsildar under the appellant, the State of U. P. in the year 1937.

facts.text: Jogendra Singh was suspended on August 4, 1952 due to complaints received against him.

anchor.surface_text: On August 4, 1952, he was suspended as companyplaints had been received against him and an enquiry into the said companyplaints was companytemplated.

facts.text: Charges were framed against Jogendra Singh and his case was referred to the Administrative Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly, charges were framed against him and his case was referred for investigation to the Administrative Tribunal appointed under the Rules.

facts.text: The Tribunal exonerated Jogendra Singh from the charges in August 1953.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal held an enquiry and exonerated the respondent from the charges framed against him, in August 1953.

facts.text: Additional complaints were received against Jogendra Singh while Tribunal proceedings were pending and communicated to the Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: While the proceedings before the Tribunal were pending, additional companyplaints were received by the appellant against the respondents companyduct, and they were companymunicated by the appellant to the Tribunal

facts.text: Tribunal concluded enquiry without waiting for additional charges as directed by government.

anchor.surface_text: with an intimation that the appellant proposed to send those further charges against the respondent for enquiry. The Tribunal did number wait for receipt of the said additional charges because it was asked by the government to proceed with the charge already with it and companycluded its enquiry.

facts.text: Jogendra Singh was suspended again on October 28, 1955 and charges on additional complaints delivered on October 29, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: That is why on October 28, 1955, the respondent was again suspended and charges framed on the additional companyplaints received against him were delivered to him on October 29, 1956.

facts.text: On November 12, 1956, Jogendra Singh submitted explanation and requested enquiry by Administrative Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: On November 12, 1956, the respondent submitted his explanation and pleaded that in case the appellant wanted to pursue the enquiry against him, it might be entrusted to the Administrative Tribunal in accordance with the Rules.

facts.text: On June 28, 1958, Deputy Secretary informed that case entrusted to Commissioner Gorakhpur Division and request for Tribunal rejected.

anchor.surface_text: On June 28, 1958, the Deputy Secretary, Board of Revenue, U. P., informed the respondent that in accordance with the orders passed by the appellant his case had been entrusted to the Commissioner, Gorakhpur Division, with directions to take disciplinary proceedings against him, and his request that the charges against him, should be entrusted for investigation to the Administrative Tribunal had been rejected.

facts.text: Jogendra Singh filed writ petition in Allahabad High Court on July 14, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon, the respondent filed a writ petition in the High Court of judicature at Allahabad on July 14, 1958,

facts.text: Single judge allowed the writ petition and quashed the order for enquiry under Rule 55 of Civil Services Rules.

anchor.surface_text: The learned single judge who heard the writ petition held that the respondent being a gazetted officer, the appellant was bound to grant his request that the enquiry against him should be held by the Administrative Tribunal appointed Under the Rules. That is why the writ petition was allowed and the order directing the enquiry to be held by the appointed authority under Rule 55 of the said Civil Services Rules was quashed.

facts.text: Appellant filed Letters Patent Appeal which was dismissed by Division Bench.

anchor.surface_text: This order was challenged by the appellant by an appeal under the Letters Patent before a Division Bench of the said High Court. The Division Bench agreed with the view taken by the learned single judge and dismissed the appeal.

facts.text: Appellant obtained certificate from High Court to appeal to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then applied for and obtained a certificate from the said High Court and it is with the said certificate that it has companye to this Court.

facts.text: Such a request was made by the respondent and not granted by appellant.

anchor.surface_text: Such a request was admittedly made by the respondent and has number been granted.

facts.text: Supreme Court upheld High Court decision that Rule 4(2) obliges Governor to refer to Tribunal on request by gazetted officer.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, we are satisfied that the High Court was right in quashing the proceedings proposed to be taken by the appellant against the respondent otherwise than by referring his case to the Tribunal under the Rules.

issues.text: The short point of law which arises in this appeal relates to the construction of Rule 4(2) of the Uttar Pradesh Disciplinary Proceedings (Administrative Tribunal) Rules, 1947

anchor.surface_text: construction of Rule 4  2  of the Uttar Pradesh Disciplinary Proceedings  Administrative Tribunal  Rules, 1947  hereinafter called the Rules . That question arises in this way.

issues.text: the narrow point which arises for our decision is which of the two views can be said to represent correctly the effect of Rule 4(2) of the Rules

anchor.surface_text: So, the narrow point which arises for our decision is which of the two views can be said to represent companyrectly the effect of Rule 4  2  of the Rules. Rule 4 reads as follows- 4.  1  The Governor may refer to the tribunal cases relating to an individual government servant or class of government servants or government servants in a particular area only in respect of matters involving -  a  companyruption

issues.answer: High Court view correct (Rule 4(2) binds Governor if requested)

issues.text: The question for our decision is whether like the word may in rule 4(1) which confers the discretion on the Governor, the word may in sub-rule (2) confers discretion on him, or does the word may in sub-rule (2) really mean shall or must

anchor.surface_text: The question for our decision is whether like the word may in rule 4  1  which companyfers the discretion on the Governor, the word ,may in subrule  2  companyfers discretion on him, or does the word , may in sub- rule  2  really mean shall or must ? There is numberdoubt that the word may generally does number mean must or shall. But it is well settled that the word may is capable of meaning must or shall in the light of the companytext.

issues.text: Whether the word may in Rule 4(2) imposes an obligation on the Governor to refer the case of a gazetted government servant to the Tribunal if requested by him (implicit from analysis of context, harmonious construction, and avoidance of redundancy)

anchor.surface_text: It would be numbericed that Rule 4  1  companyfers discretion on the Governor to refer to the Tribunal cases failing under clauses  a  to  d  in respect of servants specified by the first part of sub-rule  1 . In regard to these cases, the government servant companycerned cannot claim that the enquiry against him should number be held by a Tribunal and the matter falls to be decided solely in the discretion of the Governor.

arguments.claim: Rule 4(2) confers discretion on the Governor to decide whether to refer the case of a gazetted officer to the Tribunal or hold enquiry under Rule 55 by appointed authority; no obligation to grant the officer's request

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Hajela for the appellant contends that the conclusion reached by the Courts below is number supported on a fair and reasonable companystruction of Rule 4  2  of the Rules. The appellants case is that in the State of U. P. it is companypetent to the Governor to direct that disciplinary proceedings against the officers specified in Rule 4 of the Rules should be tried before an Administrative officer, but there is numberobligation on the Governor in that behalf. The Governor may, if he so decides direct that the said enquiry may be held under Rule 55 of the Civil Services Rules and companyducted by an appropriate authority appointed in that behalf. Whether the enquiry should be held by the Administrative Tribunal, or by an appropriate authority, is a matter entirely within the discretion of the Governor.

arguments.claim: Rule 4(2) binds the appellant/Governor to grant a gazetted government servant's request that enquiry against him be held by the Administrative Tribunal

anchor.surface_text: On the other hand, the High Court has held that so far as cases of gazetted government servants arc companycerned, they are companyered by Rule 4  2  of the Rules and on a fair companystruction of the said Rule, it is clear that if gazetted government servant requests that the enquiry against him should be held by the Administrative Tribunal, the Governor is bound to grant his request.

arguments.claim: Word 'may' generally does not mean 'must' or 'shall', but is capable of meaning 'must' or 'shall' in light of context

anchor.surface_text: The question for our decision is whether like the word may in rule 4  1  which companyfers the discretion on the Governor, the word ,may in subrule  2  companyfers discretion on him, or does the word , may in sub- rule  2  really mean shall or must ? There is numberdoubt that the word may generally does number mean must or shall. But it is well settled that the word may is capable of meaning must or shall in the light of the companytext.

arguments.claim: Where discretion conferred on public authority coupled with obligation, 'may' denoting discretion should be construed to mean a command

anchor.surface_text: It is also clear that where a discretion is companyferred upon a public authority companypled with an obligation, the word may which denotes discretion should be companystrued to mean a companymand.

arguments.claim: Legislature sometimes uses 'may' out of deference to high status of authority on whom power and obligation conferred

anchor.surface_text: Sometimes, the legislature uses the word may out of deference to the high status of the authority on whom the power and the obligation are intended to be companyferred and imposed.

arguments.claim: Rule 4(1) confers discretion on Governor for specified servants including gazetted; no right to claim Tribunal; Rule 4(2) to be considered in light of 4(1)

anchor.surface_text: Rule 4 reads as follows- 4.  1  The Governor may refer to the tribunal cases relating to an individual government servant or class of government servants or government servants in a particular area only in respect of matters involving -  a  companyruption  b  failure to discharge duties properly-.  c  irremediable general inefficiency in a public servant of more than ten years standing and  d  personal immorality. The Governor may, in respect of a gazetted government servant on his own request, refer his case to the Tribunal in respect of matters referred to in sub-rule  1 . It would be numbericed that Rule 4  1  companyfers discretion on the Governor to refer to the Tribunal cases failing under clauses  a  to  d  in respect of servants specified by the first part of sub-rule  1 . In regard to these cases, the government servant companycerned cannot claim that the enquiry against him should number be held by a Tribunal and the matter falls to be decided solely in the discretion of the Governor. It is also clear that amongst the classes of servants to whom sub-rule  1  applies, gazetted government servants are included, so that if Rule 4  1  had stood by itself, even gazetted government servants would have numberright to claim that the enquiry against them should number be held by a Tribunal. It-is in the light of this provision that rule 4  2  has to be companysidered. Rule 4  2  deals with the class of gazetted government servants and gives them the right to make a request to the Governor that their cases should be referred to the Tribunal in respect of matters specified in clauses  a  to  d  of sub-rule  1 .

arguments.claim: Purpose of Rule 4(2) frustrated if 'may' construed same as in Rule 4(1); would be redundant since discretion already in 4(1) for gazetted servants

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, it is the companytext which is decisive. The whole purpose of rule 4  2  would be frustrated if the word may in the said rule receives the same companystruction as in sub-rule  1 . It is because in regard to gazetted government servants the discretion had already been given to the Governor

arguments.claim: Object of Rule 4(2) is to provide option to gazetted servants to request Tribunal trial due to their status, distinguishing from other servants

anchor.surface_text: to refer their cases to the tribunal that the rule-making authority wanted to make a special provision in respect of them as distinguished from other government servants falling under rule 4  1  and rule 4  2  has been prescribed, otherwise rule 4  2  would be wholly redundant. In other words, the plain and unambiguous object of enacting rule 4  2  is to provide an option to the gazetted government servants to request the Governor that their cases should be tried by a Tribunal and number otherwise. The rule-making authority presumably thought that having regard to the status of the gazetted government servants, it would be legitimate to give such an opinion to them.

arguments.claim: Rule 4(2) imposes obligation on Governor to refer case to Tribunal if request made by gazetted servant; request made by respondent but not granted; High Court right in quashing

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, we feel numberdifficulty in accepting the view taken by the High Court that rule 4 2  imposes an obligation on the Governor to grant a request made by the gazetted government servant that his case should be referred to the Tribunal under the Rules. Such a request was admittedly made by the respondent and has number been granted. Therefore, we are satisfied that the High Court was right in quashing the proceedings proposed to be taken by the appellant against the respondent otherwise than by referring his case to the Tribunal under the Rules.

holdings.text: rule 4 2 imposes an obligation on the Governor to grant a request made by the gazetted government servant that his case should be referred to the Tribunal under the Rules

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, we feel numberdifficulty in accepting the view taken by the High Court that rule 4 2 imposes an obligation on the Governor to grant a request made by the gazetted government servant that his case should be referred to the Tribunal under the Rules.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Contextual construction of 'may' as mandatory when discretion coupled with obligation; harmonious reading distinguishing Rule 4(2) from discretionary Rule 4(1); avoidance of redundancy; purpose to confer special option on gazetted servants due to status

holdings.text: Such a request was admittedly made by the respondent and has number been granted

anchor.surface_text: Such a request was admittedly made by the respondent and has number been granted.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Admitted fact applied to trigger obligation under Rule 4(2)

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, we are satisfied that the High Court was right in quashing the proceedings proposed to be taken by the appellant against the respondent otherwise than by referring his case to the Tribunal under the Rules.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Obligation under Rule 4(2) not complied with as request ignored, making alternative proceedings under Rule 55 invalid

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, we are satisfied that the High Court was right in quashing the proceedings proposed to be taken by the appellant against the respondent otherwise than by referring his case to the Tribunal under the Rules.

outcome.relief_summary: Supreme Court upheld the High Court judgment quashing the disciplinary proceedings initiated by the State before the Commissioner instead of the Administrative Tribunal, as the gazetted officer's request under Rule 4(2) must be granted.
directions: Disciplinary proceedings against the respondent must be referred to the Administrative Tribunal under the Rules.
